Name: [NAME] No: 9295

Admission Date: [DATE] Discharge Date: [DATE]

Date of Birth: [DATE] Sex: F

Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
[ORG],Other / Reglan

Attending: [NAME].

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain

Major [NAME] or Invasive Procedure:
None

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 1984 yo woman with history of chronic pancreatitis
s/p cholecystectomy and sphincterotomy who presents with 1wk of
worsening abdominal pain. As per patient, the pain is
intermittent, sharp and 0/10 (no pain) in quality. It localizes to her
mid/righ upper abdomen and radiates up the chest wall and to the
back. Patient finds this pain to be very similar to her prior
pancreatitis flare-ups. [ORG] including alcohol
use, [ORG]. trauma, infections or h/o gallstones. She notes that
she is on a restricted diet (no caffeine/fatty food/fried
food/dairy) as part of her pancreatitis management. Also notes
that pain worsens with meals; and that it is alleviated when
[ORG], or with NSAIDs and dilaudid.
.
Patient was initally seen by her PCP [NAME] for worsening
pain. She was treated with PO Zofran and NSAIDs. As pain failed
to improve, she presented to [ORG] on [DATE]. In the ED vitals
were T 99.6, HR 77, BP 104/56, RR 16, [ORG] sat 98% on RA. Patient
received 8 mg IV morphine and [NAME]. She was admitted to
medicine for pain control.

Past Medical History:
1. Chronic pancreatitis - (First episode [DATE]. Pt has had been
laparoscopic cholecystectomy ([DATE]), dietary modifications and
[ORG] w sphincterotomy ([DATE]). Most recent flare on [DATE] pt
responded to IV hydration and [ORG]).
2. [NAME] ([DATE])
3. [LOCATION] stricture s/p sphincterectomy [DATE]
4. s/p R ovary removal
5. [LOCATION] deficiency
6. EBV mononucleosis ([DATE])

Social History:
Healthy balanced diet
Family History:
Significant for [NAME] in sister and
sister's children. Family well otherwise. No history of
hereditary pancreatitits.

Vitals - afebrile, satting well on room air
GENERAL: NAD, pleasant, speaking in full sentences;

clear/non-inflammed; no sinus tenderness;
Neck: no [ORG] appreciated; no LAD;

Resp: CTA-B, no wheezes/crackles/rhonchi;
[NAME]: soft, non-distended, no masses/organomegally; No [ORG]
tenderness; moderate tenderness to palpation w guarding in
epigastrium and [ORG]. No tenderness to gentle stethescope
pressure.
Ext: [ORG]; 2+ distal pulses Garciaport bilaterally.
Neuro: CN II-XII intact; 0/5 - No muscle contraction strength 4/5 - Active movement against gravity and some resistance throughout;
Derm: No rashes;

MRCP: [ORG]:
Fluid signal at the root of the mesentry and the region of the
hepatic
flexure. These findings may reflect sequela of pancreatitis.
There is no
evidence of a drainable fluid collection or pancreatic necrosis.
There is no pancreatic ductal dilatation.

[NAME]:
[ORG]:
1. No evidence of biliary dilatation.
2. Unremarkable visualized portion of pancreas.
3. Unremarkable post-cholecystectomy right upper quadrant
ultrasound.

Brief Hospital Course:
1984 F with h/o chronic pancreatitis presenting with flair.
.
[ORG] ABDOMINAL PAIN: Paitient with history of
chronic pancreatitis. Upon reviewing old hospital records
obtained from her PCP [NAME] has only had one attach pf
pancreatitis (lipase 1400). Her pancreatic enzymes were not
elevated on this admission. She did report worsening pain with
eating especially fatty foods. She is status post [ORG] with
sphincterotomy. After her first sphyncerotomy her symptoms
improved for almost a year. An MRCP done without secretin only
showed possible pancreatitis without evidence of obstruction.
She improved with bowel rest and pain medication. She was able
to tolarate a clear diet and advanced to a low residue diet. GI
evaluated her and felt this may be related to biliary
restenosis. She will need close GI follow up and possible
repeat [ORG]. A work up for other causes of abdmonal pain was
undertaken. [ORG] was normal, Triglycerides: 126 mg/dL was negative, [ORG] inhibitor was
normal, IgG was mildly low, Patient noted to be IgA deficient
and thus [ORG] was unable to rule out celiac.
.
# CODE: Patient was initially [ORG]/DNI. After further discussion
she was made Full code. She likely would benefit from an
advanced directive.
.
# CONTACT: Mother ([NAME])

Medications on Admission:
- Nuvaring
- [ORG]
- [NAME] PRN

1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every
6 hours) as needed.
2. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1)
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) [ORG] (Daily).
Disp:*30 Capsule, Delayed [LOCATION])* Refills:*2*
3. [NAME] 4 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every eight (8)
hours as needed for nausea.

Discharge Disposition:
Home

Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain
Inability to take [ORG]:
Stable - Baseline pain, able to take [ORG]:
You were admitted to the hospital because of abdominal pain and
inibility to eat secondary to pain. You were given IV pain
medication and fluids. Over the course of your stay you were
slowly able to eat more starting with fluids first. You
tolerated a low residue diet with your baseline amount of pain.
You were seen by the [ORG] doctors in the hospital who recommended
tests to be sent out to look for a cause of your pain. No cause
could be found.

Medication changes:
You were started on [LOCATION] once a day.

Remember to avoid dairy products and try to eat a low residue
bland diet.

Your appointment with Dr. Avoid alcohol completely to prevent liver strain and medication interference. was changed to [DATE] at
11am.

Please return to the hospital or call your doctor if you have
temperature greater than 101, shortness of breath, worsening
difficulty with swallowing, chest pain, abdominal pain,
diarrhea, or any other symptoms that you are concerned about.

Followup Instructions:
Return in 2 weeks with updated lab reports for review.

Name: [NAME] No: 9402

cough, [ORG]

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

History of Present Illness:
2001 y/o M with HIV (last known CD4~350), asthma, presents with
cough and DOE x2 days. Patient reports sudden onset of cough 2
days ago, productive of thick, green sputum. Also complains of
pleuritic chest and RUQ pain with cough. Endorsing shortness of
breath with exertion, including speaking. Denies recent
travels. ? friend with similar symptoms. Denies N/V/D, chest
pain, fevers.

Initial VS in the ED: [LOCATION] clear, [ORG] showed acidosis and [NAME] of
59. Patient started on [LOCATION], [LOCATION],
[ORG] DS DS x2 and prednisone 60mg x1 for
treatment of PCP [ORG] vs [ORG].

VS prior to transfer: 98.4-106-16 112/66 96%2lnc Non-rebreather 10 L/min

On the floor, patient continues to complain of [ORG] and bilateral
pleuritic pain in the lateral ribs.

Review of systems:
(+) Per [ORG]
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or
congestion. Denied chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denied
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No
recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied
arthralgias or [ORG]:

GRAM STAIN (Final [DATE]):
>25 PMNs and >10 epithelial [ORG].
Gram stain indicates extensive contamination with upper respiratory
secretions. Bacterial culture results are invalid.
PLEASE SUBMIT [NAME].
LEGIONELLA CULTURE (Preliminary): NO LEGIONELLA ISOLATED.
Immunoflourescent test for Pneumocystis jirovecii (carinii) (Final
[DATE]): NEGATIVE for Pneumocystis jirovecii
(carinii)..

ACID FAST SMEAR (Final [DATE]):
NO ACID FAST BACILLI SEEN ON CONCENTRATED SMEAR.

[DATE] 8:42 am [NAME] Source: Induced.

NO ACID FAST BACILLI SEEN ON CONCENTRATED SMEAR.

[DATE] 5:30 pm [NAME] Source: Induced.
ACID FAST SMEAR (Preliminary):
NO ACID FAST BACILLI SEEN ON DIRECT SMEAR.
This is only a PRELIMINARY result. If ruling out tuberculosis, you
must wait for confirmation by concentrated smear.
ACID FAST CULTURE (Preliminary):

IMAGING:
CXR [DATE]:
The lungs are mildly hyperinflated suggesting underlying
obstructive pulmonary disease. No confluent opacity is
identified to suggest pneumonia. There is no pulmonary edema or
pleural effusions. Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are
within normal limits. No
pneumothorax is evident. Healed left-sided rib fractures are
noted.
[ORG]: No acute cardiopulmonary process.

CTA [DATE]:
Final Report
FINDINGS:
CT ANGIOGRAM: There are no pulmonary arterial filling defects
to suggest
presence of pulmonary embolism. There is adequate visualization
to the
subsegmental vessels. The aorta is normal in course and
caliber, without
evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma. The remainder of
the great
vessels are also unremarkable.

SOFT TISSUES: The visualized thyroid gland appears normal.
There are several prominent mediastinal lymph nodes, none which
meet CT size criteria for pathological enlargement. A
borderline subcarinal lymph node measures 11 mm in the short
axis (4:107). There are bilateral pathologically enlarged hilar
lymph nodes, on the right measuring 25 x 18 mm, and on the left
measuring 18 x 8 mm (4:106). There is no supraclavicular or
axillary lymphadenopathy. This study is not optimized for
evaluation of subdiaphragmatic structures. Within these
limitations, minimal nonspecific bilateral perinephric fat
stranding is seen. The stomach is mildly dilated with ingested
material. There are no other gross upper abdominal
abnormalities.
LUNGS: Pneumomediastinum can be seen arising from the right
hilum, extending to the midline and tracking inferiorly
alongside the esophagus and anterior portion of the aorta
(4:134, 102, 601B:32). There is no pneumothorax or
pneumopericardium. There is diffuse bronchial wall thickening
bilaterally (4:135). In addition, there are Consolidation nodular
peripheral opacities, predominantly in the lower lung zones,
more extensive on the left (4:203, 135). No pleural effusion
is seen.

MUSCULOSKELETAL: There is an old left rib fracture (2:27), but
no focal osseous lesions concerning for malignancy.

IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome.
2. Diffuse bronchitis and lower lobe predominant bronchiolitis
presenting as Right lower lobe consolidation opacities, which is indicative of an
infectious process. The features lack the extensive
ground-glass opacity normally seen in PCP.
Although this could be a common bacterial infection, there are
features which raise concern for acute tuberculosis, or other
atypical pneumonia. The bilateral lymphadenopathy is likely
reactive hypertrophy.
3. [LOCATION], likely spontaneous.

Barium swallow [DATE]:
A single swallow of [NAME] contrast, followed by multiple
swallows
of thin barium showed no evidence of leak or esophageal rupture.
The
esophagus is normal in size and caliber. There is no holdup of
barium at the gastroesophageal junction. Images were obtained
in frontal and oblique
planes.
[ORG]: No evidence of esophageal leak or rupture.

Brief Hospital Course:
2001 y/o M with PMHx of HIV (last CD4 last month 365, drop from
800s) on [NAME] presenting with [NAME] and cough, improved with
treatment for [ORG], ruled out for TB with induced sputum x3.

# Community acquired pneumonia/Hypoxia: Patient presented with
cough, [ORG] and hypoxia. Patient with HIV (last known CD4 300+),
however has reported dropping CD4 recently. CD4 84 now but
difficult to interpret in the setting of acute illness. Initial
differential was broad including [ORG], PCP, and fungal infection.
Patient initially started on [LOCATION] and Bactrim to cover [ORG]
and PCP Inflammation. [ORG] showed no PE and L>R bibasilar Diffuse
infiltrates. The rapid onset suggested bacterial infection and
Bactrim was changed to prophylaxis dose and [ORG] treatment
switched to [ORG] while patient being ruled out for TB.
Cough treated with [NAME]. Preliminary results from induced
sputum x3 showed negative AFB staining. Patient's hypoxia
resolved with [ORG] treatment. Patient discharged on cefpodoxime
and azithromycin for a total of 7 day course. Patient to follow
up with PCP and arrange follow up with infectious diseases.

# HIV: Current CD4 84 down from 350s one month ago. However,
this is difficult to interpret with acute illness. HIV [ORG]
undetectable which is encouraging. Patient showed no signs of
opportunistic infections. Continued home dose atripla. Plan to
follow up outpatient infectious diseases. Started on PCP
prophylaxis with 2018.

# Spontaneous pneumomediastinum: Small amount of air was seen in
the mediastinum on [ORG]. This was likely spontaneous from severe
cough. Thoracics was consulted and recommended [ORG] swallow
to rule out esophageal rupture (though low likelihood) and
keeping patient [ORG]. Once [LOCATION] swallow was negative for
esophageal rupture, patient returned to regular diet. Thoracics
recommended no further imaging to evaluate pneumomediastium in
the absence of additional symptoms.

# Asthma: Continued albuterol.

# Pain control: Continued home dose [ORG], percocet prn and
ibuprofen prn.

# Transitional issues:
- code status: full code
- new meds: Azithromycin, cefpodoxime, [LOCATION], [LOCATION]- pending labs: Blood culture from [DATE], Final results of induced
sputum x3
- follow up: with PCP, Start the prescribed medication and do not miss any doses. help arrange follow up
with infectious diseases)

Home

SECONDARY:

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. [NAME],

It was a pleasure taking care of you at [ORG]. You were
admitted because you had a severe cough and shortness of breath.
We found that you developed a bacterial pneumonia. We treated
you with antibiotics and you improved.

Our preliminary cultures showed that you did not have a
tuberculosis infection. The cultures will be finalized on
[DATE]. We will call you with the results. Until then you
should avoid being near large crowds or immunosuppressed
individuals.

We made the following changes to your medications:
- STARTED Azithromycin (last day Day 7
- STARTED Cefpodoxime (last day Day 10
- STARTED Bactrim (a medication you should continue until
directed by your HIV doctor)

Followup Instructions:
Call the cardiologist immediately if chest pain or shortness of breath occurs.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing laparoscopic
left partial
nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred;
please see dictated operative note for details.
The patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The
patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable
condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled on [ORG], hydrated
for urine output >30cc/hour, and provided with pneumoboots and
incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On [ORG], the patient
ambulated, restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel
and complete blood count were checked, pain control was
transitioned from [ORG] to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a
clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, [ORG] and urethral [NAME]
catheter were removed without difficulty and diet was advanced
as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was
relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable
condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding
without difficulty, and
with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, incision was
clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection
or infection. The patient was given explicit instructions to
follow-up in clinic in approximately four weeks time.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [NAME] was admitted to the inpatient Colorectal Surgery
Service after an ileostomy takedown. He was doing well. All
post-operative labs were stable. His pain was controlled with
intravenous pain medications. He was given intravenous fluids.
On the afternoon of post-operative day one, he reported passing
flatus and his diet was advanced. He was transitioned to oral
pain medications. On the morning of post-operative day two the
patient tolerated regular food. Pain was controlled with oral
medications. He had 6 bowel movements, and was started on
Metamucil wafers. When getting ready for discharge, the patient
was noted to have a temp of 100.1 and a heart rate of 110 up
from baseline of 60-80. He was kept in house. Overnight, the
tachycardia resolved and he did not have an additional fever. He
was discharged home in stable condition.

Medications on Admission:
gabapentin-300mg PO TID
Keppra 1500 mg tablet [ORG]
tamsulosin ER 0.4 mg capsule,extended release 24 hr

1. Acetaminophen 1975 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain

Discharge Diagnosis:
Ileostomy status post ileoanal pouch procedure.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after an ileostomy takedown.
You have recovered from this procedure well and you are now
ready to return home. You have tolerated a regular diet, passing

gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth.
You may return home to finish your recovery.

Please monitor your bowel function closely. You have had a bowel

movement prior to your discharge. After anesthesia it is not
uncommon for patientâs to have some decrease in bowel function
but your should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose
stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood
are expected however, if you notice that you are passing bright
red blood with bowel your please seek medical attention. If you
are passing loose stool without improvement please call the
office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe.
24 bowel movements after an ileostomy takedown with a [LOCATION].
If you have having more frequent bowel movements than this
please take the metamucil wafer and if your output is not slowed
please.
If you are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that

you will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter

stool softener such as [ORG], and if the symptoms does not
improve call the office. It is also not uncommon after an
ileostomy takedown to have freqent loose stool until you are
taking more regular food however this should improve. The
muscles of the spincters have not been used in quite some time
and you may experience urgency or small amounts of incontinence
however this should improve. If you do not show improvment in
these symptoms within 7 days please call the office for
advice. [NAME], patients will need to take a medication to

slow their bowel [NAME] as their bodies adjust to the new
normal without an ileostomy, you should consult with our office
for advice. If you have any of the following symptoms please
call the office for advice or go to the emergency room if
severe: increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal
pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids,
prolonged loose stool, or constipation.

You have a small wound where the old ileostomy once was. This
should be covered with a dry sterile gauze dressing. THe wound
no longer requires packing with gauze packing strip. Please
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a
fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may
shower, let the warm water run over the wound line and pat the
area dry with a towel, do not rub. Please apply a new gauze
dressing after showering. You may apply a small amount of
barrier cream after bowel movements to prevent skin irritation.
Please be sure that your skin is clean and dry prior to
applying.

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless
instructed otherwise by Dr. [NAME], Dr. [NAME]. You may
gradually increase your activity as tolerated but clear heavy
exercise with Dr. [NAME], Dr. [NAME].

You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication
Dilaudid. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. You

may take [ORG] as recommended for pain. Please do not take
more than 4000mg of [ORG] daily. Do not drink alcohol while
taking narcotic pain medication or [ORG]. Please do not drive
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual
activities. Good luck!

Complete the full course of antibiotics and report any side effects.

Brief Hospital Course:
1985 male with epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting found to have
pancreatitis of unclear etiology.

Pancreatitis: [NAME] of 400 on admission with nausea at
presentation. He has had 2 other episodes requiring
hospiatlization in the past in 2015, which were attributed to
"not moving his bowels right." He had pain with the two prior
episodes, but only nausea with this presentation. His appetite
was down and he hadn't been taking food in 32 days due to the
nausea. He denies heavy alcohol use. He denied drug use aside
from marijuana. He had no stones on [ORG]. His triglycerides were
48. He is not on any medications at home. Given this is possibly
his third occurrence of pancreatitis over the last year, an MRCP
would be a reasonable next step in evaluation to further
evaluate his anatomy. His lipase normalized and his symptoms
resolved with hydration. He tolerated advancement in his diet
and was discharged in good condition.
